Comment: This command info is generated from fig
Name: pandoc

Arguments.Name: -o
Arguments.Description: Write output to FILE instead of stdout

Arguments.Name: --data-dir
Arguments.Description: Specify the user data directory to search for pandoc data files

Arguments.Name: -d
Arguments.Description: Specify a set of default option settings

Arguments.Name: --fail-if-warnings
Arguments.Description: Exit with error status if there are any warnings

Arguments.Name: --log
Arguments.Description: Write log messages in machine-readable JSON format to FILE

Arguments.Name: --list-input-formats
Arguments.Description: List supported input formats, one per line

Arguments.Name: --list-output-formats
Arguments.Description: List supported output formats, one per line

Arguments.Name: --list-extensions
Arguments.Description: List supported extensions for FORMAT, one per line, preceded by a + or -  indicating whether it is enabled by default in FORMAT

Arguments.Name: --list-highlight-languages
Arguments.Description: List supported languages for syntax highlighting, one per line

Arguments.Name: --list-highlight-styles
Arguments.Description: List supported styles for syntax highlighting, one per line

Arguments.Name: --shift-heading-level-by
Arguments.Description: Shift heading levels by a positive or negative integer

Arguments.Name: --indented-code-classes
Arguments.Description: Specify classes to use for indented code blocks–for example, perl,numberLines or haskell. Multiple classes may be separated by spaces or commas

Arguments.Name: --default-image-extension
Arguments.Description: Specify a default extension to use when image paths/URLs have no extension. This allows you to use the same source for formats that require different kinds of images. Currently this option only affects the Markdown and LaTeX readers

Arguments.Name: --file-scope
Arguments.Description: Parse each file individually before combining for multifile documents. This will allow footnotes in different files with the same identifiers to work as expected

Arguments.Name: -F
Arguments.Description: Specify an executable to be used as a filter transforming the pandoc AST after the input is parsed and before the output is written

Arguments.Name: -L
Arguments.Description: Transform the document in a similar fashion as JSON filters, but use pandoc’s built-in Lua filtering system

Arguments.Name: -M
Arguments.Description: Set the metadata field KEY to the value VAL

Arguments.Name: --metadata-file
Arguments.Description: Read metadata from the supplied YAML (or JSON) file

Arguments.Name: -p
Arguments.Description: Preserve tabs instead of converting them to spaces

Arguments.Name: --tab-stop
Arguments.Description: Specify the number of spaces per tab

Arguments.Name: --track-changes
Arguments.Description: Specifies what to do with insertions, deletions, and comments produced by the MS Word `Track Changes` feature

Arguments.Name: accept
Arguments.Description: Processes all the insertions and deletions and ignores comments

Arguments.Name: reject
Arguments.Description: Ignores all the insertions and deletions and ignores comments

Arguments.Name: all
Arguments.Description: Includes all insertions, deletions, and comments, wrapped in spans with insertion, deletion, comment-start, and comment-end classes, respectively

Arguments.Name: --extract-media
Arguments.Description: Extract images and other media contained in or linked from the source document to the path DIR, creating it if necessary, and adjust the images references in the document so they point to the extracted files

Arguments.Name: --abbreviations
Arguments.Description: Specifies a custom abbreviations file, with abbreviations one to a line. If this option is not specified, pandoc will read the data file abbreviations from the user data directory or fall back on a system default

Arguments.Name: -s
Arguments.Description: Produce output with an appropriate header and footer (e.g. a standalone HTML, LaTeX, TEI, or RTF file, not a fragment). This option is set automatically for pdf, epub, epub3, fb2, docx, and odt output

Arguments.Name: --template
Arguments.Description: Use the specified file as a custom template for the generated document

Arguments.Name: -V
Arguments.Description: Set the template variable KEY to the value VAL when rendering the document in standalone mode. If no VAL is specified, the key will be given the value true

Arguments.Name: -D
Arguments.Description: Print the system default template for an output FORMAT. Templates in the user data directory are ignored

Arguments.Name: --print-default-data-file
Arguments.Description: Print a system default data file. Files in the user data directory are ignored

Arguments.Name: --eol
Arguments.Description: Manually specify line endings: crlf (Windows), lf (macOS/Linux/UNIX), or native (line endings appropriate to the OS on which pandoc is being run). The default is native

Arguments.Name: native
Arguments.Description: Line endings appropriate to the OS on which Pandoc is being run

Arguments.Name: --dpi
Arguments.Description: Specify the default dpi (dots per inch) value for conversion from pixels to inch/centimeters and vice versa

Arguments.Name: --wrap
Arguments.Description: Determine how text is wrapped in the output (the source code, not the rendered version)

Arguments.Name: auto
Arguments.Description: Attempts to wrap lines to the column width specified by --columns (default 72)

Arguments.Name: none
Arguments.Description: Will not wrap lines at all

Arguments.Name: preserve
Arguments.Description: Attempts to preserve the wrapping from the source document

Arguments.Name: --columns
Arguments.Description: Specify length of lines in characters. This affects text wrapping in the generated source code

Arguments.Name: --toc
Arguments.Description: Include an automatically generated table of contents (or, in the case of latex, context, docx, odt, opendocument, rst, or ms, an instruction to create one) in the output document. It has no effect on man, docbook4, docbook5, or jats output

Arguments.Name: --toc-depth
Arguments.Description: Specify the number of section levels to include in the table of contents

Arguments.Name: --strip-comments
Arguments.Description: Strip out HTML comments in the Markdown or Textile source, rather than passing them on to Markdown, Textile or HTML output as raw HTML. This does not apply to HTML comments inside raw HTML blocks when the markdown_in_html_blocks extension is not set

Arguments.Name: --no-highlight
Arguments.Description: Disables syntax highlighting for code blocks and inlines, even when a language attribute is given

Arguments.Name: --highlight-style
Arguments.Description: Specifies the coloring style to be used in highlighted source code

Arguments.Name: --print-highlight-style
Arguments.Description: Prints a JSON version of a highlighting style, which can be modified, saved with a .theme extension, and used with --highlight-style

Arguments.Name: --syntax-definition
Arguments.Description: Instructs pandoc to load a KDE XML syntax definition file, which will be used for syntax highlighting of appropriately marked code blocks

Arguments.Name: -H
Arguments.Description: Include contents of FILE, verbatim, at the end of the header

Arguments.Name: -B
Arguments.Description: Include contents of FILE, verbatim, at the beginning of the document body

Arguments.Name: -A
Arguments.Description: Include contents of FILE, verbatim, at the end of the document body

Arguments.Name: --resource-path
Arguments.Description: List of paths to search for images and other resources. If --resource-path is not specified, the default resource path is the working directory

Arguments.Name: --request-header
Arguments.Description: Set the request header NAME to the value VAL when making HTTP requests. If you’re behind a proxy, you also need to set the environment variable http_proxy to http://

Arguments.Name: --no-check-certificate
Arguments.Description: Disable the certificate verification to allow access to unsecure HTTP resources

Arguments.Name: --self-contained
Arguments.Description: Produce a standalone HTML file with no external dependencies, using data: URIs to incorporate the contents of linked scripts, stylesheets, images, and videos

Arguments.Name: --html-q-tags
Arguments.Description: Use <q> tags for quotes in HTML. This option only has an effect if the smart extension is enabled

Arguments.Name: --ascii
Arguments.Description: Use only ASCII characters in output. Currently supported for XML, HTML formats, CommonMark, gfm, Markdown, roff ms , and to a limited degree LaTeX, roff man output uses ASCII by default

Arguments.Name: --reference-links
Arguments.Description: Use reference-style links, rather than inline links, in writing Markdown or reStructuredText

Arguments.Name: --reference-location
Arguments.Description: Specify whether footnotes (and references, if reference-links is set) are placed at the end of the current (top-level) block, the current section, or the document. Currently only affects the markdown writer

Arguments.Name: --markdown-headings
Arguments.Description: Specify whether to use ATX-style (#-prefixed) or Setext-style (underlined) headings for level 1 and 2 headings in Markdown output

Arguments.Name: --top-level-division
Arguments.Description: Treat top-level headings as the given division type in LaTeX, ConTeXt, DocBook, and TEI output

Arguments.Name: -N
Arguments.Description: Number section headings in LaTeX, ConTeXt, HTML, Docx, ms, or EPUB output. By default, sections are not numbered

Arguments.Name: --number-offset
Arguments.Description: Offset for section headings in HTML output (ignored in other output formats)

Arguments.Name: --listings
Arguments.Description: Use the listings package for LaTeX code blocks. The package does not support multi-byte encoding for source code. To handle UTF-8 you would need to use a custom template

Arguments.Name: -i
Arguments.Description: Make list items in slide shows display incrementally

Arguments.Name: --slide-level
Arguments.Description: Specifies that headings with the specified level create slides (for beamer, s5, slidy, slideous, dzslides). Headings above this level in the hierarchy are used to divide the slide show into sections; headings below this level create subheads within a slide

Arguments.Name: --section-divs
Arguments.Description: Wrap sections in <section> tags (or <div> tags for html4), and attach identifiers to the enclosing <section> (or <div>) rather than the heading itself

Arguments.Name: --email-obfuscation
Arguments.Description: Specify a method for obfuscating mailto: links in HTML documents references . The default is none

Arguments.Name: none
Arguments.Description: Leaves mailto: links as they are

Arguments.Name: references
Arguments.Description: Obfuscates mailto: links by printing their letters as decimal or hexadecimal character references

Arguments.Name: --id-prefix
Arguments.Description: Specify a prefix to be added to all identifiers and internal links in HTML and DocBook output, and to footnote numbers in Markdown and Haddock output

Arguments.Name: -T
Arguments.Description: Specify STRING as a prefix at the beginning of the title that appears in the HTML header (but not in the title as it appears at the beginning of the HTML body)

Arguments.Name: -c
Arguments.Description: Link to a CSS style sheet. This option can be used repeatedly to include multiple files. They will be included in the order specified

Arguments.Name: --reference-doc
Arguments.Description: Use the specified file as a style reference in producing a docx or ODT file

Arguments.Name: --epub-cover-image
Arguments.Description: Use the specified image as the EPUB cover. It is recommended that the image be less than 1000px in width and height. Note that in a Markdown source document you can also specify cover-image in a YAML metadata block

Arguments.Name: --epub-metadata
Arguments.Description: Look in the specified XML file for metadata for the EPUB. The file should contain a series of Dublin Core elements

Arguments.Name: --epub-embed-font
Arguments.Description: Embed the specified font in the EPUB. This option can be repeated to embed multiple fonts. Wildcards can also be used

Arguments.Name: --pdf-engine
Arguments.Description: Use the specified engine when producing PDF output

Arguments.Name: --pdf-engine-opt
Arguments.Description: Use the given string as a command-line argument to the pdf-engine

Arguments.Name: -C
Arguments.Description: Process the citations in the file, replacing them with rendered citations and adding a bibliography. Citation processing will not take place unless bibliographic data is supplied, either through an external file specified using the --bibliography option or the bibliography field in metadata, or via a references section in metadata containing a list of citations in CSL YAML format with Markdown formatting. The style is controlled by a CSL stylesheet specified using the --csl option or the csl field in metadata. (If no stylesheet is specified, the chicago-author-date style will be used by default)

Arguments.Name: --bibliography
Arguments.Description: Set the bibliography field in the document’s metadata to FILE, overriding any value set in the metadata. If you supply this argument multiple times, each FILE will be added to bibliography. If FILE is a URL, it will be fetched via HTTP. If FILE is not found relative to the working directory, it will be sought in the resource path

Arguments.Name: --csl
Arguments.Description: Set the csl field in the document’s metadata to FILE, overriding any value set in the metadata. (This is equivalent to --metadata csl=FILE.) If FILE is a URL, it will be fetched via HTTP. If FILE is not found relative to the working directory, it will be sought in the resource path and finally in the csl subdirectory of the pandoc user data directory

Arguments.Name: --citation-abbreviations
Arguments.Description: Set the citation-abbreviations field in the document’s metadata to FILE, overriding any value set in the metadata. If FILE is a URL, it will be fetched via HTTP. If FILE is not found relative to the working directory, it will be sought in the resource path and finally in the csl subdirectory of the pandoc user data directory

Arguments.Name: --natbib
Arguments.Description: Use natbib for citations in LaTeX output. It is intended for use in producing a LaTeX file that can be processed with bibtex

Arguments.Name: --biblatex
Arguments.Description: Use biblatex for citations in LaTeX output. It is intended for use in producing a LaTeX file that can be processed with bibtex or biber

Arguments.Name: --mathjax
Arguments.Description: Use MathJax to display embedded TeX math in HTML output. TeX math will be put between (...) (for inline math) or [...] (for display math) and wrapped in <span> tags with class math. Then the MathJax JavaScript will render it. The URL should point to the MathJax.js load script. If a URL is not provided, a link to the Cloudflare CDN will be inserted

Arguments.Name: --mathml
Arguments.Description: Convert TeX math to MathML (in epub3, docbook4, docbook5, jats, html4 and html5). This is the default in odt output. Note that currently only Firefox and Safari (and select e-book readers) natively support MathML

Arguments.Name: --webtex
Arguments.Description: Convert TeX formulas to tags that link to an external script that converts formulas to images. The formula will be URL-encoded and concatenated with the URL provided. For SVG images you can for example use --webtex https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.latex?. If no URL is specified, the CodeCogs URL generating PNGs will be used (https://latex.codecogs.com/png.latex?). Note: the --webtex option will affect Markdown output as well as HTML, which is useful if you’re targeting a version of Markdown without native math support

Arguments.Name: --katex
Arguments.Description: Use KaTeX to display embedded TeX math in HTML output. The URL is the base URL for the KaTeX library. That directory should contain a katex.min.js and a katex.min.css file. If a URL is not provided, a link to the KaTeX CDN will be inserted

Arguments.Name: --gladtex
Arguments.Description: Enclose TeX math in <eq> tags in HTML output. The resulting HTML can then be processed by GladTeX to produce SVG images of the typeset formulas and an HTML file with these images embedded

Arguments.Name: --dump-args
Arguments.Description: Print information about command-line arguments to stdout, then exit. This option is intended primarily for use in wrapper scripts

Arguments.Name: --ignore-args
Arguments.Description: Ignore command-line arguments (for use in wrapper scripts). Regular pandoc options are not ignored
